title: Teaching Computer Science: Node.js and AWS Hands-On Labs
lead: Teaching Computer Science effectively means combining theory with practice. Node.js and AWS hands-on labs give students real-world skills: server-side JavaScript, cloud deployment, and modern DevOps workflows. This guide covers how to teach both.

sections.title: Why Teach Node.js for Computer Science?
content: Node.js is ideal for teaching server-side programming: it uses JavaScript (familiar to many students), has a rich ecosystem, and powers real-world applications. Students can build APIs, web servers, and full-stack apps from day one.

highlights.title: Single Language for Frontend and Backend
highlights.text: JavaScript runs in the browser and on the server with Node.js. Students learn one language for the full stack, reducing context-switching and accelerating projects.

highlights.title: Event-Driven and Asynchronous
highlights.text: Node.js teaches event loops, callbacks, promises, and async/await—concepts essential for modern programming. Understanding async helps students write efficient, scalable code.

highlights.title: npm and the JavaScript Ecosystem
highlights.text: Students learn package management, dependencies, and module systems. npm is the largest software registry, giving access to libraries for APIs, databases, and utilities.

sections.title: Core Node.js Concepts to Teach
content: Structure your Node.js curriculum around these foundational topics that students will use in real projects.

list.item: Modules and require/import: How Node.js organizes code, CommonJS vs ES modules, and structuring a project
File system (fs): Reading and writing files, streams, and working with directories
HTTP and Express: Creating web servers, routing, middleware, and REST APIs
Async patterns: Callbacks, Promises, async/await, and error handling
Environment and configuration: process.env, .env files, and managing different environments
Testing: Unit tests with Jest or Mocha, integration tests, and debugging

sections.title: Why AWS Hands-On Labs Matter for Learning
content: Cloud skills are in high demand. AWS hands-on labs give students real experience with EC2, S3, Lambda, and more—without expensive hardware. Learning by doing builds confidence and employability.

strategies.title: Learn by Doing
strategies.text: Hands-on labs replace passive reading with active practice. Students provision resources, deploy code, and troubleshoot—skills that stick because they're applied.

strategies.title: Real-World Architecture
strategies.text: Labs expose students to scalability, security, and cost management. They learn how production systems work, not just theoretical concepts.

strategies.title: Preparation for AWS Certifications
strategies.text: Structured labs align with AWS Certified Cloud Practitioner, Solutions Architect, or Developer certifications. Students can validate skills employers recognise.

sections.title: Essential AWS Labs for Computer Science Students
content: Start with these lab types to build a practical AWS curriculum.

list.item: EC2: Launch virtual machines, configure security groups, SSH access, and run Node.js applications on Linux
S3: Create buckets, upload/download objects, static website hosting, and understanding storage classes
Lambda: Serverless functions with Node.js, triggers, and event-driven architecture
API Gateway: Expose REST APIs, integrate with Lambda, and handle CORS and authentication
RDS or DynamoDB: Database setup, connections from Node.js, and basic queries
IAM: Users, roles, policies, and least-privilege access—critical for security

sections.title: Combining Node.js and AWS in Hands-On Projects
content: Integrate Node.js and AWS in project-based labs. Students deploy real applications to the cloud and learn the full lifecycle.

highlights.title: Deploy Node.js to EC2
highlights.text: Build a simple Express API locally, then deploy to an EC2 instance. Cover PM2, nginx, environment variables, and domain configuration.

highlights.title: Serverless API with Lambda and API Gateway
highlights.text: Create Lambda functions in Node.js, expose them via API Gateway, and call from a frontend. Introduces serverless architecture without managing servers.

highlights.title: Store Data in S3 from Node.js
highlights.text: Use the AWS SDK in Node.js to upload files, list objects, and serve static assets. Connects application logic to cloud storage.

highlights.title: CI/CD with AWS (CodePipeline, CodeBuild)
highlights.text: Automate deployment: push code, trigger builds, run tests, and deploy. Students learn DevOps practices used in industry.

sections.title: Best Practices for Teaching Node.js and AWS
content: Effective teaching balances structure with exploration.

list.item: Start simple: Begin with basic HTTP servers and static S3 sites before moving to Lambda and complex architectures
Use sandbox accounts: AWS Free Tier and educational credits reduce cost. Set up billing alerts to avoid surprises
Emphasise security: Teach IAM, least privilege, and secrets management from the start
Iterate and debug: Encourage students to break things and fix them. Real learning happens when troubleshooting
Document and reflect: Have students document their lab steps and reflect on what they learned
